isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - ENGINE CRANK INHIBIT SYSTEM (ECI)

svcsubproc.title: SIGNAL FUNCTION
svcsubproc.para: The ECM uses the enable circuit to control engine cranking. The ECM prevents cranking motor operation: whenever the engine is running or whenever a vehicle with an automatic transmission is not in neutral.

svcsubproc.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
svcsubproc.para: With the key ON, the ECM enables the crank relay if the engine is not running and if 12 volts is present at terminal 10 with an automatic transmission.
With a manual transmission, the ECM programming doesn't look at terminal 10 in enabling the crank inhibit relay.
To enable the crank inhibit relay, the ECM sets terminal 35 LOW (ground state). To disable the crank relay, terminal 35 is HIGH (12 volts).

svcsubproc.title: Crank Inhibit Relay
svcsubproc.para: Turning the key to the start position applies power to the crank inhibit relay at pin 2. If the relay is enabled by the ECM, the relay is energized and applies ignition voltage to the cranking motor magnetic switch control coil.

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor Magnetic Switch
svcsubproc.para: The crank motor magnetic switch is used to switch battery power to the crank motor solenoid when the crank inhibit relay is energized. With thermo overcrank protection installed the magnetic switch is grounded through the overcrank thermo couple.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: The ECM does not monitor the cranking system circuits. There are no fault codes for this system.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION
svcsubproc.para: The engine starting system is controlled by the Electronic Control Module (ECM). While cranking the engine, vehicle battery voltage may momentarily drop below 6 volts, causing the ECM to shut down. When voltage comes back up, the ECM will resume operation. The Crank Inhibit Relay (385) has a 2-second delay feature that allows the engine to continue to crank (for up to 2 seconds) while the ECM is OFF, so the engine starts properly.
The ECM disables the cranking system when:

item.para: The automatic transmission is not in neutral.

svcsubproc.para: Components include:

item.para: Neutral Position Switch with automatic transmission

svcsubproc.title: SYSTEM OPERATION
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to the circuit diagram Figure 3.39
(manual xmsn) Figure 3.40
(automatic xmsn) for the following discussion. Energizing the engine starting system requires a series of events by the cranking system components. The Engine Crank Inhibit Relay (385) receives inputs from several sources and if all conditions are present, the Start Relay (387) is energized.

svcsubproc.title: Crank Inhibit Relay (385)
svcsubproc.para: The Crank Inhibit Relay has two major functions.

step1.para: The ECM signal must "enable" the Crank Inhibit Relay for the cranking system to operate.
The relay must keep the engine cranking if vehicle battery voltage drops below 6 volts during cranking, causing the ECM to go off line momentarily.

svcsubproc.para: The Crank Inhibit Relay has 5 pins. To energize the Start Relay, the Engine Crank Inhibit relay interacts with the other cranking system components.

note.para: The Crank Inhibit Relay PIN numbers shown in the circuit diagram are different than the relay harness connector cavity numbers.

step1.para: Crank Inhibit Relay Pin 5 is connected by circuit 97DE/97H to ECM terminal 35. For the relay to enable the cranking system, ECM terminal 35 must be LOW (0 volts). Note that the ECM switches terminal 35 between LOW ( 0v) and HIGH (12v), to either "enable" or "disable" the Crank Inhibit Relay. The circuit diagrams shows terminal states (HIGH or LOW) for various conditions.

svcsubproc.para: Example 1: With the engine running, ECM terminal 35 will be HIGH, preventing the crank system from engaging.

Example 2: With an automatic transmission, if the shift selector is NOT in neutral when preparing to start the engine, ECM terminal 35, would be HIGH and the crank system would not engage. Placing the transmission in neutral would cause ECM terminal 35 to switch LOW and enable the cranking system.

step1.para: Crank Inhibit Relay Pin 1 receives power from 10A fuse F4 (H1 fuse w/FBC) when the key is ON. With an automatic transmission, the power must first pass through the Neutral Position Switch (closed when in neutral). With a manual transmission, the power from F4 (or H1 w/FBC) is present whenever the key is ON.

Crank Inhibit Relay Pin 2 receives ignition voltage when the start switch is engaged (push button or key switch). This energizes the Crank Inhibit Relay (if steps 1, 2 and 3 occurred) causing voltage from terminal 3 to energize the Start Relay (387).
Crank Inhibit Relay Pin 3 delivers output voltage on circuit 17A to the Start Relay when the Crank Inhibit Relay is energized.
Crank Inhibit Relay Pin 4 is grounded by circuit 97-GD at the relay bracket.

svcsubproc.title: Start Relay (387)
svcsubproc.para: The Start Relay (387) is energized by voltage on circuit 17A from the energized Crank Inhibit Relay (385). When the Start Relay is energized, battery voltage from "B" terminal of cranking motor solenoid is applied through the Start Relay contacts (E to A) to the "S" terminal of crank motor to energize the cranking motor. The Start Relay is a suppressed relay. The Start Relay has an internal diode to prevent voltage spikes from damaging electronic components in the vehicle system.

svcsubproc.title: Thermo Overcrank Protection (OCP)
svcsubproc.para: On vehicles equipped with Thermo Overcrank Protection cranking motors, the ground circuit for the Start Relay is through the Thermo Overcrank thermocouple. If the cranking motor temperature reaches a specified limit, the thermocouple opens, preventing further engine cranking until the cranking motor cools.

svcsubproc.title: Neutral Position Switch
svcsubproc.para: With an Allison AT/MT automatic transmission, a normally open (NO) Neutral Position Switch is used to turn power ON or OFF in circuit 97AU.

With the transmission in neutral, the switch is closed applying power to Crank Inhibit Relay pin 1 and to ECM terminal 10. On the circuit diagrams, ECM terminal 10 is labeled DDS (Driveline Disengagement Status). The 12 volts at ECM terminal 10 tells the ECM that the Neutral Position switch is closed and that the transmission is in neutral.

With an Allison WT (electronic transmission controls), the neutral position switch is not used as the Allison WT Electronic Control Module determines shifter position. With the transmission in neutral, ignition power from the transmission Vehicle Interface Module (VIM) Neutral Start Relay is delivered on circuit 97AU to the Crank Inhibit Relay at pin 1. From pin 1, circuit 97L/97A applies the ignition voltage to ECM DDS terminal 10.

When the vehicle has an automatic transmission (AT or MT), the clutch switch connector (paragraph 2.4) has a jumper connecting circuits 97L and 97A, completing the circuit between Crank Inhibit Relay (385) pin 1 and ECM terminal 10.

With an automatic transmission, ECM terminal 10 is programmed to expect 12 volts on circuit 97A when the shifter is in neutral and 0 volts when the shifter is not in neutral. The circuit diagram shows terminal states for various conditions.

The Prolink 9000 can be used to monitor the Neutral Position Switch. When the switch is closed (transmission in neutral), the Prolink (using PTO/Clutch Switch Status) indicates clutch ON, meaning the driveline is disengaged.

svcsubproc.title: Clutch Pedal Switch (386)
svcsubproc.para: The clutch pedal switch is used for cruise control, engine brakes etc. The ECM is programmed so that the input from the DDS terminal 10 has no effect on enabling or disabling the cranking system.
The Prolink 9000 EST can be used to monitor the Clutch Switch position. When the clutch switch is open (clutch depressed), the Prolink indicates clutch ON, meaning the driveline is disengaged.

svcsubproc.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
svcsubproc.para: Electronic Control Module terminals 10 (only with automatic xmsn) and 35 are directly involved with enabling the Crank Inhibit Relay. The ECM and VPM (VPM stores information for the ECM) are programmed differently for automatic or manual transmissions.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Terminal 10 (DDS)
svcsubproc.para: ECM terminal 10 receives input (12 volts or 0 volts) from either the clutch switch with a manual transmission or neutral position indication with an automatic transmission.

svcsubproc.title: Automatic Transmission
svcsubproc.para: With an automatic transmission, the ECM uses the input to determine the voltage signal on ECM terminal 35. If the transmission is in neutral, terminal 10 will be HIGH (12v) and terminal 35 will LOW (0v). If the transmission is not in neutral, terminal 10 will be LOW (0v) and terminal 35 will be HIGH (12v).

svcsubproc.title: Manual Transmission
svcsubproc.para: With a manual transmission, the ECM does not use input from terminal 10 to set terminal 35.

svcsubproc.title: ECM Terminal 35 (ECI)
svcsubproc.para: ECM terminal 35 is connected by circuit 97H to Crank Inhibit Relay pin 5. Based on inputs to ECM terminal 10 and engine operating conditions, the ECM either sets terminal 35 LOW (0v) or HIGH (12v). With ECM terminal 35 LOW, the Crank Inhibit Relay is "enabled." If the ECM terminal 35 is HIGH, then the Crank Inhibit Relay is NOT "enabled."

svcsubproc.title: ECM Programming
svcsubproc.para: The ECM "enables" the Crank Inhibit Relay if:

item.para: The transmission is in neutral (with automatic transmission).

svcsubproc.para: If these conditions do not exist, the Crank Inhibit Relay is not enabled and the engine will not crank.

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: The ECM "enables" or "disables" the engine cranking system with the Engine Crank Inhibit (ECI) relay. There are no ECM diagnostics for this system. Perform the following tests to find the cause of a No Crank condition.

step1.para: Before troubleshooting, make sure that the batteries are fully charged! Check battery cables and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage. Voltage tests will give misleading readings if the batteries are not fully charged.

Before troubleshooting a particular circuit, inspect connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands etc. The wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
